column4: Ackman's Pershing Square raises stake in Howard Hughes Corp.- filing
column5: BOSTON (Reuters) - Activist investor William Ackman's hedge fund Pershing Square Capital Management has raised its stake in real estate company Howard Hughes Corp. HHC.N, according to a regulatory filing made on Wednesday.
column6: The New York-based investment firm reported having a 14.8% stake in the company, or 6.4 million shares, including 2.2 million shares of common stock and 4.2 million underlying forward purchase contracts.
column7: Previously it had an economic interest of 12.6%, including common stock and swaps, according to a regulatory filing made roughly a year ago.
column8: Pershing Square has owned Howard Hughes shares for years and Ackman serves as chairman of the company’s board.

column4: Howard Hughes announces management reshuffle, to sell assets worth $2 billion
column5: (Reuters) - Howard Hughes Corp HHC.N, which counts activist investor William Ackman as chairman, said on Monday it would sell about $2 billion of non-core assets following a strategic review and announced a management reshuffle.
column6: Shares of the company were down 18.4% at $104.70 in extended trading.
column7: “There was a belief that the entire company would be sold or the company would go private,” said Vahid Khorsand, an analyst with BWS Financial.
column8: Ackman, however, said in a conference call with analysts that the company would only consider selling itself if a substantial premium was offered.
column9: The company is currently valued at over $5 billion.
column10: In June, the real estate developer hired Centerview Partners to explore strategic alternatives that included a potential sale of the company.
column11: The asset sales along with changes to the company’s organizational structure announced on Monday is expected to reduce overhead costs by $45 million to $50 million per year.
column12: The company named Paul Layne as CEO, effective immediately. He will replace David Weinreb who, along with the president Grant Herlitz, will step down from the company.
column13: Both Weinreb and Herlitz had signed a 10-year employment agreement with the company in 2017.
column14: Layne was most recently the president of the company’s Central Region, which include properties The Woodlands, The Woodlands Hills and Bridgeland in Texas.
column15: Ackman said Layne’s appointment along with the company’s headquarters move from Dallas to Houston will enable Howard Hughes to be more profitable and free-cash-flow-generative.
column16: Ackman’s Pershing Square Capital Management owned 2.77% of the Howard Hughes’ common stock at the end of June, according to Refinitiv data, and the firm had a total economic exposure of 12.6% through common stock and swaps, according to a regulatory filing.
column17: Howard Hughes was formed in 2010 as a tax-free spinoff from General Growth Properties.

column4: Howard Hughes appoints new CEO, explores $2 bln asset sales
column5: Oct 21 (Reuters) - Howard Hughes Corp on Monday named a new chief executive officer and said it would sell about $2 billion of non-core assets, following the real estate developer’s strategic review process.
column6: Paul Layne, president of the company’s Central Region has been named CEO, effective immediately.
column7: In June, the real estate developer hired Centerview Partners to explore strategic alternatives that included a potential sale of the company. (Reporting by Shanti S Nair in Bengaluru; Editing by Shailesh Kuber)

column4: Howard Hughes Corp hires Centerview to explore options, including sale
column5: (Reuters) - Howard Hughes Corp has hired Centerview Partners to explore strategic alternatives that include a sale of the company, the real estate developer said on Thursday.
column6: A joint venture or spin-off of a portion of assets, recapitalization and changes to corporate structure were among the options being explored, the company said.
column7: “The board and management are determined to close the significant gap between our share price and the company’s underlying net asset value,” Chief Executive David Weinreb said in a statement.
column8: Shares of the company were up 35% at $125.00 in afternoon trading. The company’s stock had fallen the same 35% since it hit a high of $160.62 in September 2014.
column9: CNBC had earlier reported on the search for strategic alternatives, citing people familiar with the matter.
column10: The company has diverse assets and does not lend itself to the recurring and predictable cash flows real estate investors may be looking for, CNBC said, citing sources familiar with the board’s thinking.
column11: Activist investor William Ackman, who runs Pershing Square Capital Management, is chairman of the company. His Pershing Square funds owned 2.7% of the company’s common stock at the end of March, and the firm had a total economic exposure of 12.6% through common stock and swaps, according to a regulatory filing.
column12: Howard Hughes was formed in 2010 as a tax-free spinoff from General Growth Properties.

column4: REFILE-Howard Hughes hires Centerview Partners to explore strategic alternatives - CNBC
column5: (Corrects day in paragraph 1 to Thursday from Monday)
column6: June 27 (Reuters) - Real estate developer Howard Hughes Corp has hired Centerview Partners to explore strategic alternatives that include a sale of the company, CNBC reported here on Thursday, citing people familiar with the matter.
column7: Shares of the company surged nearly 23% on the news.
column8: It is not clear whether the company is well suited to the public markets as it has diverse assets that does not lend itself to the recurring and predictable cash flows real estate investors may be looking for, said the report, citing sources familiar with the board’s thinking.
column9: The stock’s poor performance led management and the board to explore a sale, according to the report. Bankers are also exploring joint ventures or spinoffs as part of their mandate, the report said.
column10: The company was not immediately available for a comment.
